The Self Help Scam

2025, Jan 26    

Here’s the unvarnished truth: the self-help scene is basically a high-stakes flea market for your insecurities, peddling magic-bullet promises that translate into little more than repackaged clichés. It’s a multi-billion-dollar juggernaut getting rich off your anxieties, and if you dare to complain that your life didn’t miraculously improve after their three-step “secret to happiness,” they’ll respond with a perfectly curated smile and point out that you clearly aren’t trying hard enough. Meanwhile, the gurus pocket your money, blame you for any lack of progress, and wave yet another overpriced seminar in front of your face. Throw in a few buzzwords—maybe something about manifesting your “best self” or “vibrational alignment”—and suddenly common sense is spun into an elusive, high-ticket commodity. In reality, if you actually want to fix something, you might skip the carnival of motivational speeches and look for, say, an evidence-based therapist. But where’s the fun (and profit) in that?
